1866-01.Notes: Duse Mohamed Ali (sometimes also referred to as Duse Mohamad Ali, or alternately Duse Mohamed) was born in Alexandria but spent most of his life outside of his native Egypt.

1876-01.Notes: Duse Mohamed Ali (sometimes also referred to as Duse Mohamad Ali, or alternately Duse Mohamed) was born in Alexandria but spent most of his life outside of his native Egypt.

1886-01.Notes: The exact dates of his New York trip are uknown. We do know that he traveled there as an actor as part of a theatre tour for Wilson Barret's Star Theatre Company. Duffield dates his arrival to NYC between 1886 and 188

1887-01.Notes: The exact dates of his New York trip are uknown. We do know that he traveled there as an actor as part of a theatre tour for Wilson Barret's Star Theatre Company. Duffield dates his arrival to NYC between 1886 and 188
Between 1882 and the early 1900s Duse Mohamed Ali works as an itinerant actor and freelance journalist.

1889-09.Notes: Other sources identify his birthdate as 9-15-1890 and the birthplace as Sunny Ville, also in Clarendon Parish. Cooper says that McKay was born in Sunny Ville in 1890 and left at the age of 7.

1896-01.Notes: In his memoir Leaves of an Active Life serialized in the Nigerian journal The Comet between 1937/06/12 and 1938/03/05, Ali recounts visiting the Caribbean and Florida in his early career, but does not provide specific dates; According to historian Ian Duffield this trip must have taken place sometimes in the early to mid 1890s.

1897-01.Notes: Other sources identify his birthdate as 9-15-1890 and the birthplace as Sunny Ville, also in Clarendon Parish. Cooper says that McKay was born in Sunny Ville in 1890 and left at the age of 7.
Cooper bases these dates on McKay's autobiographical writings. These are the years that McKay lived with his brother, U'Theo.

1901-01.Notes: Cooper bases these dates on McKay's autobiographical writings. These are the years that McKay lived with his brother, U'Theo.

1907-01.Notes: McKay enrolled in trade school in Kingston beginning in January 1907, but the school was destroyed by the earthquake on January 14, 1907.
McKay worked as an apprentice to a master craftsman for two years. It was here that he met Walter Jekyll.

1909-01.Notes: McKay worked as an apprentice to a master craftsman for two years. It was here that he met Walter Jekyll.

1910-01.Notes: Cooper describes McKay moving to Kingston "probably late in 1909 or early in 1910."

1911-01.Notes: Attends the Universal Races Congress with W.E.B. Du Bois and other leading intellectuals of the time. Sets up an office at 158 Fleet Street in London and founds the African Times and Orient Review (1912-1920)

1912-01.Notes: Cooper describes McKay moving to Kingston "probably late in 1909 or early in 1910."
Cooper describes McKay's arrival in the US in "late summer of 1912."
McKay enrolled at the Tuskegee Institute.

1912-10.Notes: McKay enrolled at the Tuskegee Institute.
McKay transferred to Kansas State College.

1914-01.Notes: McKay transferred to Kansas State College.
McKay spent part of this time period working on the railroad and traveling throughout the US.

1919-01.Notes: McKay spent part of this time period working on the railroad and traveling throughout the US.
"McKay left for England in the early fall of 1919" (Cooper 108)

1920-12.Notes: "McKay left for England in the early fall of 1919" (Cooper 108)

1921-01.Notes: Attends the Universal Races Congress with W.E.B. Du Bois and other leading intellectuals of the time. Sets up an office at 158 Fleet Street in London and founds the African Times and Orient Review (1912-1920)

Originally traveled to NYC for a business meeting about cacao import but ended up staying for ten years. While in the US, he became a regular contributor to Garvey's Negro World and head ed UNIA's African Affairs department between 1922-1924. Ali would leave the UNIA by the end of 1924, some months before Garvey's arrest in 1925. After spending a few years in the Midwest, he returned to New York in 1926 and helped found a cultural organization by the name of America-Asia Association Inc

1922-01.Notes: During his stay in Detroit, Duse Mohamed Ali founded the Detroit Central Islamic Society, which Duffield argues was loosely based on the London Central Islamic Society. In 1925 he went on to found the American Asiatic Society, which he then left in 1926.

1923-01.Notes: In the early 1920s, Ali founded the Ämericän' African Oriental Trading Company whose businesses are based in Chicago. According to Duffield, the address of this Company was 3202-Cottage Grove Avenue, Chicago.

1924-09.Notes: We do not know the reason for this visit.

1925-01.Notes: During his stay in Detroit, Duse Mohamed Ali founded the Detroit Central Islamic Society, which Duffield argues was loosely based on the London Central Islamic Society. In 1925 he went on to found the American Asiatic Society, which he then left in 1926.

1926-08.Notes: birthplace; student at the Frères Bretons de l'Instruction Chrétienne; also attended Pinchinat High School and Pétion High School

1931-01.Notes: Originally traveled to NYC for a business meeting about cacao import but ended up staying for ten years. While in the US, he became a regular contributor to Garvey's Negro World and head ed UNIA's African Affairs department between 1922-1924. Ali would leave the UNIA by the end of 1924, some months before Garvey's arrest in 1925. After spending a few years in the Midwest, he returned to New York in 1926 and helped found a cultural organization by the name of America-Asia Association Inc

Ali emigrates to Nigeria in 1931, where he first works as a contributor for The Nigerian Daily Times, and then as the editor for the Nigerian Daily Telegraph. In July 1933 he founded the journal The Comet, which he edited until his death in 1945.

1931-09.Notes: We do not know the reason for this visit.

1940-01.Notes: birthplace; student at the Frères Bretons de l'Instruction Chrétienne; also attended Pinchinat High School and Pétion High School
attends Aimé Césaire's seminar (May-December 1944); publishes Etincelles, founds journal La Ruche

1945-01.Notes: Ali emigrates to Nigeria in 1931, where he first works as a contributor for The Nigerian Daily Times, and then as the editor for the Nigerian Daily Telegraph. In July 1933 he founded the journal The Comet, which he edited until his death in 1945.

1946-01.Notes: attends Aimé Césaire's seminar (May-December 1944); publishes Etincelles, founds journal La Ruche
flew here from Port-au-Prince and departed on a boat for Cherbourg
arrived here on a boat from New York; heads to Paris, where picked up by Aimé Césaire
connects w/Bloncourt and Alexis; hangs out w/Francis Joachim Roy and French intelligentsia etc; attended both Sciences Po and La Sorbonne

1947-01.Notes: connects w/Bloncourt and Alexis; hangs out w/Francis Joachim Roy and French intelligentsia etc; attended both Sciences Po and La Sorbonne
World Federation of Democratic Youth send him to the International Festival of Students and Youth – spends summer laying rail tracks from Samac to Sarajevo in Yugoslavia
during this period, joins the "Group of Young Poets" created by Elsa Triolet

1950-01.Notes: during this period, joins the "Group of Young Poets" created by Elsa Triolet

1950-12.Notes: meets Pablo Neruda, Jorge Amado at Chateau de Dobris

1951-08.Notes: meets Pablo Neruda, Jorge Amado at Chateau de Dobris
Third World Festival of Youth and Students for Peace; sees Guillén there [Cuba journal 9/11/1965 mistakenly says he was there summer 1952]
expelled for criticism of Stalinist purges

1952-01.Notes: Maison de la pensée française (connects w/Aragon and Bloncourt); discovered and expelled

1952-03.Notes: expelled for criticism of Stalinist purges
embarks on the Francesco Morosini; learns of Batista's coup onboard March 10
invited by Guillén; arrested by Fulgencio Batista; expelled

1952-05.Notes: invited by Guillén; arrested by Fulgencio Batista; expelled

1952-06.Notes: Maison de la pensée française (connects w/Aragon and Bloncourt); discovered and expelled

1952-12.Notes: World Peace Council (founded by Cominform in 1950 to combat US "warmongering" and nuclearization)– 12/12-12/19
on the invitation of painter Renato Guttuso; stay in the Alcron Hotel [leaves from here to Brazil before heading to Chile: figure out these dates]
Congreso Continental de la Cultura organized w/Neruda (as his secretary) and Amado in April 1953

1953-03.Notes: Stalin obsequies in Moscow took place between March 7 and 13

1954-01.Notes: militant in Brazilian Communist Party; writing under the name "Walter Miranda"

1955-01.Notes: Works for Ghana's Department of Education; City ambiguous

1956-01.Notes: Plebiscite officer for the UN; City ambiguous
militant in Brazilian Communist Party; writing under the name "Walter Miranda"
granted a visa thanks to Léopold Sedar Senghor's intervention
Moulin d'Andé w/Richard Wright, Maurice Pons, Suzanne Lipinska
First International Conference of Negro Writers and Artists organized by journal Présence Africaine

1956-09.Notes: Moulin d'Andé w/Richard Wright, Maurice Pons, Suzanne Lipinska

1957-01.Notes: First International Conference of Negro Writers and Artists organized by journal Présence Africaine

1957-12.Notes: invited by François Duvalier to return from exile and assume post of Foreign Affairs Minister

1959-03.Notes: invited by François Duvalier to return from exile and assume post of Foreign Affairs Minister

invited to participate in revolutionary operations by Che Guevara on Guillén's recommendation; important role in the National Press, serves as Minister of Exterior Relations, journalist for Revolución and Hoy, broadcaster on Radio Cuba, organizer of Congreso Cultural de la Havana (1967)

1960-01.Notes: On leave from position in Ghana, meets and marries wife; City ambiguous

invited to participate in revolutionary operations by Che Guevara on Guillén's recommendation; important role in the National Press, serves as Minister of Exterior Relations, journalist for Revolución and Hoy, broadcaster on Radio Cuba, organizer of Congreso Cultural de la Havana (1967)
sent as correspondent with Revolución; meets up w/Alexis to discuss reconciling 2 factions of Haitian communism

1960-11.Notes: meets with Mao Tse-tung and Chou En-lai

1961-02.Notes: Jacques Stephen Alexis arrives to prepare invasion of Haiti

1962-01.Notes: Works as resident tutor; City ambiguous

1962-10.Notes: Cuban Missile Crisis; Cultural Congress of Havana January 4-11, 1968

1963-01.Notes: Works as resident tutor; City ambiguous

1963-04.Notes: puis une semaine en Allemagne avec Jahn ou?

1963-05.Notes: À l'occasion de la création de l'Organisation de l'unité africaine

1966-01.Notes: Meets article author at Caribbean Arts Movement gathering

1968-01.Notes: Returns to Jamaica after PhD in England, potentially here up til 1991 when he moves to NYU

1969-07.Notes: sent as journalist for Granma to cover Pan-African Festival of Algiers

1971-01.Notes: Nairobi University, City of Nairobi fellowship; Naming ceremony 1972 in Limura, Kenya

1972-01.Notes: Nairobi University, City of Nairobi fellowship; Naming ceremony 1972 in Limura, Kenya

1978-01.Notes: Mona, University of the West Indies

1984-01.Notes: attends Congress of Pen Club as representative of UNESCO
attends 8th World Congress of Poets presided over by Senghor as representative of UNESCO

1985-01.Notes: attends 8th World Congress of Poets presided over by Senghor as representative of UNESCO

1987-01.Notes: Gives annual Sir Winston Scott Memorial Lecture; City ambiguous

1988-01.Notes: Lives in Jamaica until 1991. Home destroyed during Hurricane Gilbert (1988).

1989-10.Notes: dernière intervention à l’Assemblée nationale : le 29 novembre

1989-11.Notes: dernière intervention à l’Assemblée nationale : le 29 novembre

1989-12.Notes: à partir de cette date, il n’y a plus de traces de séjours de Césaire ailleurs qu’en Martinique

1990-04.Notes: Mackey interview, while Brathwaite was Regents' Professor at UC Santa Cruz

1991-09.Notes: Leaves Jamaica for NYU (splits time w/ Caribbean home)

1993-01.Notes: Conversation with Nathaniel Mackey at Poets House

1993-11.Notes: Conversation with Nathaniel Mackey at Poets House

1994-01.Notes: Attended celebration for birth of Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o's child (Spring 1994)
Leaves Jamaica for NYU (splits time w/ Caribbean home)

1996-11.Notes: Conference at the University of Memphis, "The Caribbean: South of the South"

2001-01.Notes: Address as of 2001: Department of History, University of the West Indies, Mona, Kingston 7, Jamaica

2003-03.Notes: West Indian Lit Conference at UMiami

2003-06.Notes: attends events surrounding Aimé Césaire's 90th birthday

2005-02.Notes: sent w/Foreign Affairs Minister Michel Barnier and writer Régis Debray by Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin to lecture at Institut français d'Haïti on 2005-02-22

2009-09.Notes: Teaches Tpcs in Caribbean Lit at NYU
